text: Weisspriess and Wilfrid made their way toward Milan together, silently
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: smoking, after one attempt at conversation, which touched on Vittoria's
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: marriage; but when they reached Monza the officer slapped his degraded
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: brother in arms upon the shoulder, and asked him whether he had any
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: inclination to crave permission to serve in Hungary.  For his own part,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Weisspriess said that he should quit Italy at once; he had here to skewer
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the poor devils, one or two weekly, or to play the mightily generous; in
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: short, to do things unsoldierly; and he was desirous of getting away from
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the country.  General Schoneck was at Monza, and might arrange the matter
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: for them both.  Promotion was to be looked for in Hungary; the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: application would please the General; one battle would restore the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: lieutenant's star to Wilfrid's collar.  Wilfrid, who had been offended
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: by his companion's previous brooding silence, nodded briefly, and they
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: stopped at Monza, where they saw General Schoneck in the morning, and
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Wilfrid being by extraordinary favour in civilian's dress during his
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: leave of absence, they were jointly invited to the General's table at
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: noon, though not to meet any other officer.  General Schoneck agreed with
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Weisspriess that Hungary would be a better field for Wilfrid; said he
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: would do his utmost to serve them in the manner they wished, and
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: dismissed them after the second cigar.  They strolled about the city,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: glad for reasons of their own to be out of Milan as long as the leave
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: permitted.  At night, when they were passing a palace in one of the dark
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: streets, a feather, accompanied by a sharp sibilation from above, dropped
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: on Wilfrid's face.  Weisspriess held the feather up, and judged by its
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: length that it was an eagle's, and therefore belonging to the Hungarian
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Hussar regiment stationed in Milan.  "The bird's aloft," he remarked.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: His voice aroused a noise of feet that was instantly still.  He sent a
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: glance at the doorways, where he thought he discerned men.  Fetching a
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: whistle in with his breath, he unsheathed his sword, and seeing that
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Wilfrid had no weapon, he pushed him to a gate of the palace-court that
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: had just cautiously turned a hinge.  Wilfrid found his hand taken by a
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: woman's hand inside.  The gate closed behind him.  He was led up to an
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: apartment where, by the light of a darkly-veiled lamp, he beheld a young
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Hungarian officer and a lady clinging to his neck, praying him not to go
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: forth.  Her Italian speech revealed how matters stood in this house.  The
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: officer accosted Wilfrid: "But you are not one of us!"  He repeated it to
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the lady: "You see, the man is not one of us!"
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: She assured him that she had seen the uniform when she dropped the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: feather, and wept protesting it.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: "Louis, Louis! why did you come to-night! why did I make you come!  You
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: will be slain.  I had my warning, but I was mad."
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: The officer hushed her with a quick squeeze of her inter-twisted fingers.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: "Are you the man to take a sword and be at my back, sir?" he said; and
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: resumed in a manner less contemptuous toward the civil costume:
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: "I request it for the sole purpose of quieting this lady's fears."
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Wilfrid explained who and what he was.  On hearing that he was General
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Pierson's nephew the officer laughed cheerfully, and lifted the veil from
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the lamp, by which Wilfrid knew him to be Colonel Prince Radocky, a most
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: gallant and the handsomest cavalier in the Imperial service.  Radocky
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: laughed again when he was told of Weisspriess keeping guard below.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: "Aha!  we are three, and can fight like a pyramid."
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: He flourished his hand above the lady's head, and called for a sword.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: The lady affected to search for one while he stalked up and down in the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: jaunty fashion of a Magyar horseman; but the sword was not to be
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: discovered without his assistance, and he was led away in search of it.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: The moment he was alone Wilfrid burst into tears.  He could bear anything
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: better than the sight of fondling lovers.  When they rejoined him,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Radocky had evidently yielded some point; he stammered and worked his
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: underlip on his moustache.  The lady undertook to speak for him.  Happily
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: for her, she said, Wilfrid would not compromise her; and taking her
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: lover's hand, she added with Italian mixture of wit and grace:
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: "Happily for me, too, he does.  The house is surrounded by enemies; it is
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: a reign of terror for women.  I am dead, if they slay him; but if they
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: recognize him, I am lost."
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Wilfrid readily leaped to her conclusion.  He offered his opera-hat and
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: civil mantle to Radocky, who departed in them, leaving his military cloak
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: in exchange.  During breathless seconds the lady hung kneeling at the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: window.  When the gate opened there was a noise as of feet preparing to
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: rush; Weisspriess uttered an astonished cry, but addressed Radocky as "my
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Pierson!" lustily and frequently; and was heard putting a number of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: meaningless questions, laughing and rallying Pierson till the two passed
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: out of hearing unmolested.  The lady then kissed a Cross passionately,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: and shivered Wilfrid's manhood by asking him whether he knew what love
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: was.  She went on:
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: "Never, never love a married woman!  It's a past practice.  Never!
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Thrust a spike in the palm of your hands drink scalding oil, rather than
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: do that."
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: "The Prince Radocky is now safe," Wilfrid said.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: "Yes, he is safe; and he is there, and I am here: and I cannot follow
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: him; and when will he come to me?"
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: The tones were lamentable.  She struck her forehead, after she had mutely
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: thrust her hand to right and left to show the space separating her from
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: her lover.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Her voice changed when she accepted Wilfrid's adieux, to whose fate in
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the deadly street she appeared quite indifferent, though she gave him one
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: or two prudent directions, and expressed a hope that she might be of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: service to him.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: He was set upon as soon as he emerged from the gateway; the cavalry cloak
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: was torn from his back, and but for the chance circumstance of his
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: swearing in English, he would have come to harm.  A chill went through
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: his blood on hearing one of his assailants speak the name of Barto Rizzo.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: The English oath stopped an arm that flashed a dagger half its length.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Wilfrid obeyed a command to declare his name, his country, and his rank.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: It's not the prince! it's not the Hungarian!" went many whispers; and he
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: was drawn away by a man who requested him to deliver his reasons for
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: entering the palace, and who appeared satisfied by Wilfrid's ready
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: mixture of invention and fact.  But the cloak!  Wilfrid stated boldly
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: that the cloak was taken by him from the Duchess of Graatli's at Como;
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: that he had seen a tall Hussar officer slip it off his shoulders; that he
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: had wanted a cloak, and had appropriated it.  He had entered the gate of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the palace because of a woman's hand that plucked at the skirts of this
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: very cloak.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: "I saw you enter," said the man; "do that no more.  We will not have the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: blood of Italy contaminated--do you hear?  While that half-Austrian
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Medole is tip-toeing 'twixt Milan and Turin, we watch over his honour,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: to set an example to our women and your officers.  You have outwitted us
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: to-night.  Off with you!"
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Wilfrid was twirled and pushed through the crowd till he got free of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: them.  He understood very well that they were magnanimous rascals who
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: could let an accomplice go, though they would have driven steel into the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: principal.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Nothing came of this adventure for some time.  Wilfrid's reflections
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: (apart from the horrible hard truth of Vittoria's marriage, against which
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: he dashed his heart perpetually, almost asking for anguish) had leisure
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: to examine the singularity of his feeling a commencement of pride in the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: clasping of his musket;--he who on the first day of his degradation had
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: planned schemes to stick the bayonet-point between his breast-bones: he
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: thought as well of the queer woman's way in Countess Medole's adjuration
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: to him that he should never love a married woman;--in her speaking, as it
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: seemed, on his behalf, when it was but an outcry of her own acute wound.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Did he love a married woman?  He wanted to see one married woman for the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: last time; to throw a frightful look on her; to be sublime in scorn of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: her; perhaps to love her all the better for the cruel pain, in the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: expectation of being consoled.  While doing duty as a military machine,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: these were the pictures in his mind; and so well did his routine drudgery
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: enable him to bear them, that when he heard from General Schoneck that
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the term of his degradation was to continue in Italy, and from his sister
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: that General Pierson refused to speak of him or hear of him until he had
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: regained his gold shoulder-strap, he revolted her with an ejaculation of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: gladness, and swore brutally that he desired to have no advancement;
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: nothing but sleep and drill; and, he added conscientiously, Havannah
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: cigars.  "He has grown to be like a common soldier," Adela said to
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: herself with an amazed contemplation of the family tie.  Still, she
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: worked on his behalf, having, as every woman has, too strong an instinct
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: as to what is natural to us to believe completely in any eccentric
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: assertion.  She carried the tale of his grief and trials and his romantic
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: devotion to the Imperial flag, daily to Countess Lena; persisting, though
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: she could not win a responsive look from Lena's face.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: One day on the review-ground, Wilfrid beheld Prince Radocky bending from
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: his saddle in conversation with Weisspriess.  The prince galloped up to
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: General Pierson, and stretched his hand to where Wilfrid was posted as
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: marker to a wheeling column, kept the hand stretched out, and spoke
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: furiously, and followed the General till he was ordered to head his
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: regiment.  Wilfrid began to hug his musket less desperately.  Little
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: presents--feminine he knew by the perfumes floating round them,--gloves
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: and cigars, fine handkerchiefs, and silks for wear, came to his barracks.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: He pretended to accuse his sister of sending them.  She in honest delight
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: accused Lena.  Lena then accused herself of not having done so.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: It was winter: Vittoria had been seen in Milan.  Both Lena and Wilfrid
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: spontaneously guessed her to be the guilty one.  He made a funeral pyre
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: of the gifts and gave his sister the ashes, supposing that she had
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: guessed with the same spirited intuition.  It suited Adela to relate this
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: lover's performance to Lena.  "He did well!" Lena said, and kissed Adela
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: for the first time.  Adela was the bearer of friendly messages to the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: poor private in the ranks.  From her and from little Jenna, Wilfrid heard
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: that he was unforgotten by Countess Lena, and new hopes mingled with
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: gratitude caused him to regard his situation seriously.  He confessed to
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: his sister that the filthy fellows, his comrades, were all but too much
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: for him, and asked her to kiss him, that he might feel he was not one of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: them.  But he would not send a message in reply to Lena.  "That is also
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: well!"  Lena said.  Her brother Karl was a favourite with General
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Pierson.  She proposed that Adela and herself should go to Count Karl,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: and urge him to use his influence with the General.  This, however, Adela
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: was disinclined to do; she could not apparently say why.  When Lena went
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: to him, she was astonished to hear that he knew every stage of her
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: advance up to the point of pardoning her erratic lover; and even knew as
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: much as that Wilfrid's dejected countenance on the night when Vittoria's
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: marriage was published in the saloon of the duchess on Lake Como, had
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: given her fresh offence.  He told her that many powerful advocates were
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: doing their best for the down-fallen officer, who, if he were shot, or
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: killed, would still be gazetted an officer.  "A nice comfort!"  said
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Lena, and there was a rallying exchange of banter between them, out of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: which she drew the curious discovery that Karl had one of his strong
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: admirations for the English lady.  "Surely!" she said to herself;
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: "I thought they were all so cold."  And cold enough the English lady
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: seemed when Lena led to the theme.  "Do I admire your brother, Countess
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Lena?  Oh! yes;--in his uniform exceedingly."
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Milan was now full.  Wilfrid had heard from Adela that Count Ammiani and
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: his bride were in the city and were strictly watched.  Why did not
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: conspirators like these two take advantage of the amnesty?  Why were they
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: not in Rome?  Their Chief was in Rome; their friends were in Rome.  Why
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: were they here?  A report, coming from Countess d'Isorella, said that
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: they had quarrelled with their friends, and were living for love alone.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: As she visited the Lenkensteins--high Austrians--some believed her; and
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: as Count Ammiani and his bride had visited the Duchess of Graatli, it was
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: thought possible.  Adela had refused to see Vittoria; she did not even
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: know the house where Count Ammiani dwelt; so Wilfrid was reduced to find
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: it for himself.  Every hour when off duty the miserable sentimentalist
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: wandered in that direction, nursing the pangs of a delicious tragedy of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: emotions; he was like a drunkard going to his draught.  As soon as he had
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: reached the head of the Corso, he wheeled and marched away from it with a
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: lofty head, internally grinning at his abject folly, and marvelling at
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the stiff figure of an Austrian common soldier which flashed by the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: windows as he passed.  He who can unite prudence and madness, sagacity
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: and stupidity, is the true buffoon; nor, vindictive as were his
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: sensations, was Wilfrid unaware of the contrast of Vittoria's soul to his
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: own, that was now made up of antics.  He could not endure the tones of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: cathedral music; but he had at times to kneel and listen to it, and be
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: overcome.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: On a night in the month of February, a servant out of livery addressed
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: him at the barrack-gates, requesting him to go at once to a certain
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: hotel, where his sister was staying.  He went, and found there, not his
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: sister, but Countess Medole.  She smiled at his confusion.  Both she and
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the prince, she said, had spared no effort to get him reinstated in his

title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: time.  I have to speak to your husband."
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

title: Vittoria — Volume 8

title: Vittoria — Volume 8

title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

title: Vittoria — Volume 8

title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

title: Vittoria — Volume 8

title: Vittoria — Volume 8

title: Vittoria — Volume 8

title: Vittoria — Volume 8

title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

author: Meredith, George

title: Vittoria — Volume 8

title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

title: Vittoria — Volume 8

text: he was careful to hide his face.  He locked the door, and leading Merthyr
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: to an inner room, laid his watch on the table, and said: "Now, friend,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8

title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

title: Vittoria — Volume 8

author: Meredith, George

title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

author: Meredith, George

text: as the lowest in the ranks, if I might be with you all under the Chief.

author: Meredith, George

text: Rome crowns him, and Brescia is my bloody ditch, and it is deserved!
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: When I was a little younger--I am a boy still, no doubt--I had the honour
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: I discovered by chance that she had wit.  The lady is the Countess
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: hurts my vanity the more.  Perhaps: you begin to perceive that vanity
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

author: Meredith, George

text: subject with any reserve, but to Violetta belongs the merit of having
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: seen it without waiting for the signs.  First--it is a small matter, but
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: you are English--let me assure you that my wife has had no rival.  I have
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: taunted her with jealousy when I knew that it was neither in her nature
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: to feel it, nor in mine to give reason for it.  No man who has a spark of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8

text: his Maker in him could be unfaithful to such a woman.  When Lombardy was
title: Vittoria — Volume 8

title: Vittoria — Volume 8

title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Merthyr, I said proudly that I would not abandon a beaten country: and I
title: Vittoria — Volume 8

text: was admired for my devotion.  The dear old poet, Agostino, praised me.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: admired me.  Marco Sana, Giulio Bandinelli admired me.  Vast numbers
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: admired me.  I need not add that I admired myself.  I plunged into
title: Vittoria — Volume 8

text: intrigues with princes, and priests, and republicans.  A clever woman was
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: at my elbow.  In the midst of all this, my marriage: I had seven weeks of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8

text: peace; and then I saw what I was.  You feel that you are tired, when you
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: want to go another way and you feel that you have been mad when you want
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: to undo your work.  But I could not break the chains I had wrought, for I

author: Meredith, George

text: was a chief of followers.  The men had come from exile, or they had
title: Vittoria — Volume 8

text: refused to join the Roman enterprise:--they, in fact, had bound
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

title: Vittoria — Volume 8

text: you, on the ground that this admired life of mine was precious.  I will
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: stand?  I know that I cannot rely on the king's luck or on the skill of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: his generals, or on the power of his army, or on the spirit in Lombardy:
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: neither on men nor on angels.  But I cannot draw back.  I have set going
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: a machine that's merciless.  From the day it began working, every moment

text: has added to its force.  Do not judge me by your English eyes: other
title: Vittoria — Volume 8

title: Vittoria — Volume 8

text: honour said nothing, simple humanity would preserve me from leaving my
title: Vittoria — Volume 8

text: band to perish like a flock of sheep."

author: Meredith, George

title: Vittoria — Volume 8

text: king.  Whether he fights and wins, or fights and loses, I go out.  I have

text: CHAPTER XLVI
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: THE LAST
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: There is hard winter overhead in the mountains when Italian Spring walks
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the mountain-sides with flowers, and hangs deep valley-walls with flowers
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: half fruit; the sources of the rivers above are set about with fangs of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: ice, while the full flat stream runs to a rose of sunlight.  High among
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the mists and snows were the fugitives of Brescia, and those who for love
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: or pity struggled to save them wandered through the blooming vales,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: sometimes hearing that they had crossed the frontier into freedom, and as
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: often that they were scattered low in death and captivity.  Austria here,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Switzerland yonder, and but one depth between to bound across and win
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: calm breathing.  But mountain might call to mountain, peak shine to peak;
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: a girdle of steel drove the hunted men back to frosty heights and clouds,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the shifting bosom of snows and lightnings.  They saw nothing of hands
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: stretched out to succour.  They saw a sun that did not warm them, a home
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: of exile inaccessible, crags like an earth gone to skeleton in hungry
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: air; and below, the land of their birth, beautiful, and sown everywhere
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: for them with torture and captivity, or death, the sweetest. Fifteen men
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: numbered the escape from Brescia.  They fought their way twice through
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: passes of the mountains, and might easily, in their first dash Northward
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: from the South-facing hills, have crossed to the Valtelline and Engadine,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: but that in their insanity of anguish they meditated another blow, and
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: were readier to march into the plains with the tricolour than to follow
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: any course of flight.  When the sun was no longer in their blood they
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: thought of reason and of rest; they voted the expedition to Switzerland,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: that so they should get round to Rome, and descended from the crags of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the Tonale, under which they were drawn to an ambush, suffering three of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: their party killed, and each man bloody with wounds.  The mountain
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: befriended them, and gave them safety, as truth is given by a bitter
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: friend.  Among icy crags and mists, where the touch of life grows dull as
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the nail of a fore-finger, the features of the mountain were stamped on
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: them, and with hunger they lost pride, and with solitude laughter; with
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: endless fleeing they lost the aim of flight; some became desperate, a few
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: craven.  Companionship was broken before they parted in three bodies,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: commanded severally by Colonel Corte, Carlo Ammiani, and Barto Rizzo.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Corte reached the plains, masked by the devotion of Carlo's band, who
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: lured the soldiery to a point and drew a chase, while Corte passed the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: line and pushed on for Switzerland.  Carlo told off his cousin Angelo
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Guidascarpi in the list of those following Corte; but when he fled up to
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the snows again, he beheld Angelo spectral as the vapour on a jut of rock
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: awaiting him.  Barto Rizzo had chosen his own way, none knew whither.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Carlo, Angelo, Marco Sana, and a sharply-wounded Brescian lad, conceived
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the scheme of traversing the South Tyrol mountain-range toward Friuli,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: whence Venice, the still-breathing republic, might possibly be gained.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: They carried the boy in turn till his arms drooped long down, and when
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: they knew the soul was out of him they buried him in snow, and thought
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: him happy.  It was then that Marco Sana took his death for an omen, and
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: decided them to turn their heads once more for Switzerland; telling them
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: that the boy, whom he last had carried, uttered "Rome" with the flying
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: breath.  Angelo said that Sana would get to Rome; and Carlo, smiling on
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Angelo, said they were to die twins though they had been born only
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: cousins.  The language they had fallen upon was mystical, scarce
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: intelligible to other than themselves.  On a clear morning, with the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Swiss peaks in sight, they were condemned by want of food to quit their
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: fastness for the valley.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Vittoria read the faces of the mornings as human creatures base tried to
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: gather the sum of their destinies off changing surfaces, fair not meaning
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: fair, nor black black, but either the mask upon the secret of God's
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: terrible will; and to learn it and submit, was the spiritual burden of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: her motherhood, that the child leaping with her heart might live.  Not to
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: hope blindly, in the exceeding anxiousness of her passionate love, nor
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: blindly to fear; not to bet her soul fly out among the twisting chances;
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: not to sap her great maternal duty by affecting false stoical serenity:--
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: to nurse her soul's strength, and suckle her womanly weakness with the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: tsars which are poison--when repressed; to be at peace with a disastrous
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: world for the sake of the dependent life unborn; lay such pure efforts
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: she clung to God.  Soft dreams of sacred nuptial tenderness, tragic
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: images, wild pity, were like phantoms encircling her, plucking at her as
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: she went, lest they were beneath her feet, and she kept them from lodging
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: between her breasts.  The thought that her husband, though he should have
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: perished, was not a life lost if their child lived, sustained her
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: powerfully.  It seemed to whisper at times almost as it were Carlo's
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: ghost breathing in her ears: "On thee!" On her the further duty devolved;
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: and she trod down hope, lest it should build her up and bring a shock to
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: surprise her fortitude; she put back alarm.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: The mountains and the valleys scarce had names for her understanding;
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: they were but a scene where the will of her Maker was at work.  Rarely
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: has a soul been so subjected to its own force.  She certainly had the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: image of God in her mind.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Yet when her ayes lingered on any mountain gorge, the fate of her husband
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: sang within it a strange chant, ending in a key that rang sounding
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: through all her being, and seemed to question heaven.  This music framed
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: itself; it was still when she looked at the shrouded mountain-tops.  A
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: shadow meting sunlight on the long green slopes aroused it, and it hummed
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: above the tumbling hasty foam, and penetrated hanging depths of foliage,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: sad-hued rock-clefts, dark green ravines; it became convulsed where the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: mountain threw forward in a rushing upward line against the sky, there to
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: be severed at the head by cloud.  It was silent among the vines.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Most painfully did human voices affect her when she had this music;
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: speech was a scourge to her sense of hearing, and touch distressed her:
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: an edge of purple flame would then unfold the vision of things to her
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: eyes.  She had lost memory; and if by hazard unawares one idea was
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: projected by some sudden tumult of her enslaved emotions beyond known and
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: visible circumstances, her intelligence darkened with am oppressive dread
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: like that of zealots of the guilt of impiety.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Thus destitute, her eye took innumerable pictures sharp as on a brass-
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: plate: torrents, goat-tracks winding up red earth, rocks veiled with
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: water, cottage and children, strings of villagers mounting to the church,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: one woman kneeling before a wayside cross, her basket at her back, and
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: her child gazing idly by; perched hamlets, rolling pasture-fields, the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: vast mountain lines.  She asked all that she saw, "Does he live?"  but
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the life was out of everything, and these shows told of no life, neither
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: of joy nor of grief.  She could only distantly connect the appearance of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the white-coated soldiery with the source of her trouble.  They were no
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: more than figures on a screen that hid the flashing of the sword which
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: renders dumb.  She had charity for one who was footsore and sat
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: cherishing his ankle by a village spring, and she fed him, and not until
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: he was far behind, thought that he might have seen the white face of her
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: husband.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Accurate tidings could not be obtained, though the whole course of the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: vale was full of stories of escapes, conflicts, and captures.  Merthyr
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: learnt positively that some fugitives had passed the cordon.  He came
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: across Wilfrid and Count Karl, who both verified it in the most sanguine
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: manner.  They knew, however, that Major Nagen continued in the mountains.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Riding by a bend of the road, Merthyr beheld a man playing among
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: children, with one hand and his head down apparently for concealment at
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: his approach.  It proved to be Beppo.  The man believed that Count
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Ammiani had fled to Switzerland.  Barto Rizzo, he said, was in the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: mountains still, and Beppo invoked damnation on him, as the author of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: those lying proclamations which had ruined Brescia.  He had got out of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the city later than the others and was seeking to evade the outposts,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: that he might join his master--"that is, my captain, for I have only one
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: master;" he corrected the slip of his tongue appealingly to Merthyr.  His
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: left hand was being continually plucked at by the children while he
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: talked, and after Merthyr had dispersed them with a shower of small coin,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: he showed the hand, saying, glad of eye, that it had taken a sword-cut
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: intended for Count Ammiani.  Merthyr sent him back to mount the carriage,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: enjoining him severely not to speak.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: When Carlo and his companions descended from the mountains, they entered
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: a village where there was an inn recognized by Angelo as the abode of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Jacopo Cruchi.  He there revived Carlo's animosity toward Weisspriess by
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: telling the tale of the passage to Meran, and his good reasons for
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: determining to keep guard over the Countess Alessandra all the way.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Subsequently Angelo went to Jacopo for food.  This he procured, but he
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: was compelled to leave the man behind, and unpaid.  It was dark when he
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: left the inn; he had some difficulty in evading a flock of whitecoats,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: and his retreat from the village was still on the Austrian side.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Somewhat about midnight Merthyr reached the inn, heralding the carriage.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: As Jacopo caught sight of Vittoria's face, he fell with his shoulders
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: straightened against the wall, and cried out loudly that he had betrayed
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: no one, and mentioned Major Weisspriess by name as having held the point
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: of his sword at him and extracted nothing better than a nave of the hand
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: and a lie; in other words, that the fugitives had retired to the Tyrolese
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: mountains, and that he had shammed ignorance of who they were.  Merthyr
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: read at a glance that Jacopo had the large swallow and calm digestion for
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: bribes, and getting the fellow alone he laid money in view, out of which,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: by doubling the sum to make Jacopo correct his first statement, and then
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: by threatening to withdraw it altogether, he gained knowledge of the fact
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: that Angelo Guidascarpi had recently visited the inn, and had started
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: from it South-eastward, and that Major Weisspriess was following on his
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: track.  He wrote a line of strong entreaty to Weisspriess, lest that
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: officer should perchance relapse into anger at the taunts of prisoners
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: abhorring him with the hatred of Carlo and Angelo.  At the same time he
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: gave Beppo a considerable supply of money, and then sent him off, armed
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: as far as possible to speed Count Ammiani safe across the borders, if a
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: fugitive; or if a prisoner, to ensure the best which could be hoped for
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: him from an adversary become generous.  That evening Vittoria lay with
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: her head on Laura's lap, and the pearly little crescent of her ear in
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: moonlight by the window.  So fair and young and still she looked that
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Merthyr feared for her, and thought of sending her back to Countess
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Ammiani.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Her first question with the lifting of her eyelids was if he had ceased
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: to trust to her courage.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: "No," said Merthyr; "there are bounds to human strength; that is all."
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: She answered: "There would be to mine--if I had not more than human
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: strength beside me.  I bow my head, dearest; it is that.  I feel that I
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: cannot break down as long as I know what is passing.  Does my husband
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: live?"
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: "Yes, he lives," said Merthyr; and she gave him her hand, and went to her
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: bed.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: He learnt from Laura that when Beppo mounted the carriage in silence, a
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: fit of ungovernable wild trembling had come on her, broken at intervals
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: by a cry that something was concealed.  Laura could give no advice; she
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: looked on Merthyr and Vittoria as two that had an incomprehensible
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: knowledge of the power of one another's natures, and the fiery creature
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: remained passive in perplexity of minds as soft an attendant as a
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: suffering woman could have:
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Merthyr did not sleep, and in the morning Vittoria said to him, "You want
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: to be active, my friend.  Go, and we will wait for you here.  I know that
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: I am never deceived by you, and when I see you I know that the truth
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: speaks and bids me be worthy of it Go up there," she pointed with shut
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: eyes at the mountains; "leave me to pray for greater strength.  I am
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: among Italians at this inn; and shall spend money here; the poor people
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: love it."  She smiled a little, showing a glimpse of her old charitable
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: humour.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Merthyr counselled Laura that in case of evil tidings during his absence
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: she should reject her feminine ideas of expediency, and believe that she
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: was speaking to a brave soul firmly rooted in the wisdom of heaven.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: "Tell her?--she will die," said Laura, shuddering.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: "Get tears from her," Merthyr rejoined; "but hide nothing from her for a
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: single instant; keep her in daylight.  For God's sake, keep her in
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: daylight."
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: "It's too sharp a task for me."  She repeated that she was incapable of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: it.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: "Ah," said he, "look at your Italy, how she weeps! and she has cause.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: She would die in her grief, if she had no faith for what is to come.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: I dare say it is not, save in the hearts of one or two, a conscious
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: faith, but it's real divine strength; and Alessandra Ammiani has it.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Do as I bid you.  I return in two days."
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Without understanding him, Laura promised that she would do her utmost to
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: obey, and he left her muttering to herself as if she were schooling her
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: lips to speak reluctant words.  He started for the mountains with
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: gladdened limbs, taking a guide, who gave his name as Lorenzo, and talked
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: of having been 'out' in the previous year.  "I am a patriot, signore!
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: and not only in opposition to my beast of a wife, I assure you: a
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: downright patriot, I mean."  Merthyr was tempted to discharge him at
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: first, but controlled his English antipathy to babblers, and discovered
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: him to be a serviceable fellow.  Toward nightfall they heard shots up a
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: rock-strewn combe of the lower slopes; desultory shots indicating rifle-
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: firing at long range.  Darkness made them seek shelter in a pine-hut;
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: starting from which at dawn, Lorenzo ran beating about like a dog over
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the place where the shots had sounded on the foregoing day; he found a
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: stone spotted with blood.  Not far from the stone lay a military glove
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: that bore brown-crimson finger-ends.  They were striking off to a dairy-
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: but for fresh milk, when out of a crevice of rock overhung by shrubs a
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: man's voice called, and Merthyr climbing up from perch to perch, saw
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Marco Sana lying at half length, shot through hand and leg.  From him
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Merthyr learnt that Carlo and Angelo had fled higher up; yesterday they
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: had been attacked by coming who tried to lure there to surrender by
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: coming forward at the head of his men and offering safety, and "other
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: gabble," said Marco.  He offered a fair shot at his heart, too, while he
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: stood below a rock that Marco pointed at gloomily as a hope gone for
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: ever; but Carlo would not allow advantage to be taken of even the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: treacherous simulation of chivalry, and only permitted firing after he
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: had returned to his men.  "I was hit here and here," said Marco, touching
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: his wounds, as men can hardly avoid doing when speaking of the fresh
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: wound.  Merthyr got him on his feet, put money in his pocket, and led him
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: off the big stones painfully.  "They give no quarter," Marco assured him,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: and reasoned that it must be so, for they had not taken him prisoner,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: though they saw him fall, and ran by or in view of him in pursuit of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Carlo.  By this Merthyr was convinced that Weisspriess meant well.  He
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: left his guide in charge of Marco to help him into the Engadine.  Greatly
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: to his astonishment, Lorenzo tossed the back of his hand at the offer of
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: money.  "There shall be this difference between me and my wife," he
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: remarked; "and besides, gracious signore, serving my countrymen for
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: nothing, that's for love, and the Tedeschi can't punish me for it, so
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: it's one way of cheating them, the wolves!  "Merthyr shook his hand and
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: said, "Instead of my servant, be my friend;" and Lorenzo made no feeble
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: mouth, but answered, "Signore, it is much to my honour," and so they went
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: different ways.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Left to himself Merthyr set step vigorously upward.  Information from
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: herdsmen told him that he was an hour off the foot of one of the passes.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: He begged them to tell any hunted men who might come within hail that a
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: friend ran seeking them.  Farther up, while thinking of the fine nature
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: of that Lorenzo, and the many men like him who could not by the very
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: existence of nobility in their bosoms suffer their country to go through
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: another generation of servitude, his heart bounded immensely, for he
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: heard a shout and his name, and he beheld two figures on a rock near the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: gorge where the mountain opened to its heights.  But they were not Carlo
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: and Angelo.  They were Wilfrid and Count Karl, the latter of whom had
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: discerned him through a telescope.  They had good news to revive him,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: however: good at least in the main.  Nagen had captured Carlo and Angelo,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: they believed; but they had left Weisspriess near on Nagen's detachment,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: and they furnished sound military reasons to show why, if Weisspriess
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: favoured the escape, they should not be present.  They supposed that they
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: were not half-a-mile from the scene in the pass where Nagen was being
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: forcibly deposed from his authority: Merthyr borrowed Count Karl's glass,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: and went as they directed him round a bluff of the descending hills, that
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: faced the vale, much like a blown and beaten sea-cliff.  Wilfrid and Karl
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: were so certain of Count Ammiani's safety, that their only thought was to
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: get under good cover before nightfall, and haply into good quarters,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: where the three proper requirements of the soldier-meat, wine, and
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: tobacco--might be furnished to them.  After an imperative caution that
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: they should not present themselves before the Countess Alessandra,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Merthyr sped quickly over the broken ground.  How gaily the two young men
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: cheered to him as he hurried on!  He met a sort of pedlar turning the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: bluntfaced mountain-spur, and this man said, "Yes, sure enough, prisoners
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: had been taken," and he was not aware of harm having been done to them;
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: he fancied there was a quarrel between two captains.  His plan being
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: always to avoid the military, he had slunk round and away from them as
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: fast as might be.  An Austrian common soldier, a good-humoured German,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: distressed by a fall that had hurt his knee-cap, sat within the gorge,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: which was very wide at the mouth.  Merthyr questioned him, and he, while
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: mending one of his gathered cigar-ends, pointed to a meadow near the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: beaten track, some distance up the rocks.  Whitecoats stood thick on it.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Merthyr lifted his telescope and perceived an eager air about the men,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: though they stood ranged in careless order.  He began to mount forthwith,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: but amazed by a sudden ringing of shot, he stopped, asking himself in
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: horror whether it could be an execution.  The shots and the noise
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: increased, until the confusion of a positive mellay reigned above.  The
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: fall of the meadow swept to a bold crag right over the pathway, and with
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: a projection that seen sideways made a vulture's head and beak of it.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: There rolled a corpse down the precipitous wave of green grass on to the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: crag, where it lodged, face to the sky; sword dangled from swordknot at
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: one wrist, heels and arms were in the air, and the body caught midway
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: hung poised and motionless.  The firing deadened.  Then Merthyr drawing
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: nearer beneath the crag, saw one who had life in him slipping down toward
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the body, and knew the man for Beppo.  Beppo knocked his hands together
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: and groaned miserably, but flung himself astride the beak of the crag,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: and took the body in his arms, sprang down with it, and lay stunned at
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Merthyr's feet.  Merthyr looked on the face of Carlo Ammiani.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: EPILOGUE
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: No uncontested version of the tragedy of Count Ammiani's death passed
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: current in Milan during many years.  With time it became disconnected
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: from passion, and took form in a plain narrative.  He and Angelo were
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: captured by Major Nagen, and were, as the soldiers of the force
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: subsequently let it be known, roughly threatened with what he termed I
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: 'Brescian short credit.'  The appearance of Major Weisspriess and his
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: claim to the command created a violent discussion between the two
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: officers.  For Nagen, by all military rules, could well contest it.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: But Weisspriess had any body of the men of the army under his charm,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: and seeing the ascendency he gained with them over an unpopular officer,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: he dared the stroke for the charitable object he had in view.  Having
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: established his command, in spite of Nagen's wrathful protests and
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: menaces, he spoke to the prisoners, telling Carlo that for his wife's
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: sake he should be spared, and Angelo that he must expect the fate of a
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: murderer.  His address to them was deliberate, and quite courteous: he
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: expressed himself sorry that a gallant gentleman like Angelo Guidascarpi
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: should merit a bloody grave, but so it was.  At the same time he
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: entreated Count Ammiani to rely on his determination to save him.  Major
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Nagen did not stand far removed from them.  Carlo turned to him and
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: repeated the words of Weisspriess; nor could Angelo restrain his cousin's
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: vehement renunciation of hope and life in doing this.  He accused
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Weisspriess of a long evasion of a brave man's obligation to repair an
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: injury, charged him with cowardice, and requested Major Nagen, as a man
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: of honour, to drag his brother officer to the duel.  Nagen then said that
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Major Weisspriess was his superior, adding that his gallant brother
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: officer had only of late objected to vindicate his reputation with his
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: sword.  Stung finally beyond the control of an irritable temper,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Weisspriess walked out of sight of the soldiery with Carlo, to whom, at a
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: special formal request from Weisspriess, Nagen handed his sword.  Again
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: he begged Count Ammiani to abstain from fighting; yea, to strike him and
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: disable him, and fly, rather--than provoke the skill of his right hand.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Carlo demanded his cousin's freedom.  It was denied to him, and Carlo
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: claimed his privilege.  The witnesses of the duel were Jenna and another
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: young subaltern: both declared it fair according to the laws of honour,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: when their stupefaction on beholding the proud swordsman of the army
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: stretched lifeless on the brown leaves of the past year left them with
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: power to speak.  Thus did Carlo slay his old enemy who would have served
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: as his friend.  A shout of rescue was heard before Carlo had yielded up
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: his weapon.  Four haggard and desperate men, headed by Barto Rizzo, burst
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: from an ambush on the guard encircling Angelo.  There, with one thought
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: of saving his doomed cousin and comrade, Carlo rushed, and not one
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Italian survived the fight.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: An unarmed spectator upon the meadow-borders, Beppo, had but obscure
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: glimpses of scenes shifting like a sky in advance of hurricane winds.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: Merthyr delivered the burden of death to Vittoria.  Her soul had crossed
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: the darkness of the river of death in that quiet agony preceding the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: revelation of her Maker's will, and she drew her dead husband to her
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: bosom and kissed him on the eyes and the forehead, not as one who had
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: quite gone away from her, but as one who lay upon another shore whither
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: she would come.  The manful friend, ever by her side, saved her by his
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: absolute trust in her fortitude to bear the burden of the great sorrow
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: undeceived, and to walk with it to its last resting-place on earth
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: unobstructed.  Clear knowledge of her, the issue of reverent love,
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: enabled him to read her unequalled strength of nature, and to rely on her
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: fidelity to her highest mortal duty in a conflict with extreme despair.
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: She lived through it as her Italy had lived through the hours which
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: brought her face to face with her dearest in death; and she also on the
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: day, ten years later, when an Emperor and a King stood beneath the vault
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: of the grand Duomo, and the organ and a peal of voices rendered thanks to
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: heaven for liberty, could show the fruit of her devotion in the dark-eyed
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: boy, Carlo Merthyr Ammiani, standing between Merthyr and her, with old
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: blind Agostino's hands upon his head.  And then once more, and but for
title: Vittoria — Volume 8
author: Meredith, George

text: once, her voice was heard in Milan.
